tn.text: This is the name of a small village possibly located eight kilometers northwest of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a people group that descended from Zuph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"This man" refers to Elkanah.
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a woman's name. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:01:01|1:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"made her barren" or "prevented her from becoming pregnant"
The other wife would often grieve and shame Hannah.
This is Peninnah, the other wife of Elkanah. A rival is someone who competes against another person. In this case Peninnah was competing against Hannah to try to get Elkanah to love her best.

tn.ref: Hannah, why do you weep? Why do you not eat? Why is your heart sad? Am I not better to you than ten sons?
tn.text: These rhetorical questions can be translated as statements, if necessary. AT: "Hannah, you should not weep. You should eat, and your heart should be glad because I am better to you than ten sons!" or "You have little reason for sadness. I favor you and that should be enough." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Elkanah uses this expression to emphasize how important Hannah is to him. AT: "than any son could be" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Hannah begins to pray to Yahweh, and Eli watches.

Implicit information here can be made explicit. Either Hannah's tent was next to the tabernacle tent or she walked from her tent to the tabernacle to pray. AT: "Hannah rose up and went to the house of Yahweh to pray after" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Now" is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the author tells about a new person in the story. This person is the priest Eli. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The "temple" was actually a tent, but it was where the people worshiped, so it is best to translate as "temple" here.
Hannah was deeply troubled or grieved because of not having any children and being ridiculed regularly by Peninnah, her husband's other wife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Hannah's prayer to Yahweh continues.

This refers either to 1) Hannah being unable to become pregnant or 2) the way Peninnah always insulted her. The abstract noun "affliction" can be translated as a verb phrase. AT: "how I am suffering because I cannot become pregnant" or "how that woman is afflicting me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is a special plea to God to take action on Hannah's behalf. God does know what is happening to Hannah; he has not forgotten.
This phrase says almost the same thing as "call me to mind." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Eli was the chief priest, so he was in the tabernacle of God and in charge of it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: I am a woman of a sorrowful spirit
tn.text: "I am a woman who is deeply sad"

tn.ref: pouring out my soul before Yahweh
tn.text: This is an idiom that means "telling Yahweh my deepest emotions." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Do not consider your servant to be
tn.text: Hannah speaks of herself in the second person to show her humility. It can be stated in first person. AT: "Do not consider me, your servant, to be" or "Do not consider me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: I have been speaking out of the abundance of my great concern and provocation
tn.text: This is another way of saying that she has a "sorrowful spirit," as in 1:15. The abstract nouns "abundance," "concern," and "provocation" can be translated as adjectives and verbs. AT: "I have been speaking because I am very sad, and my rival has greatly provoked me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
These words both mean that Hannah is sad and annoyed because her rival has been provoking her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Peninnah irritates and annoys her.
Hannah is referring to the grief and shame she feels because Peninnah is being cruel to her.
Eli was the head priest residing over the tabernacle.

Hannah speaks of herself in the second person to show respect for Eli, the head priest. This can be stated in the first person. AT: "Let me, your servant, find" or "Let me find" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Here seeing represents judging or deciding the value of something. AT: "in your judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "her face" represents Hannah herself. You can make this a separate sentence, if needed. AT: "and ate. She was" or "and ate. People could see that she was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
God knew what was happening to Hannah; he had not forgotten. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:01:11|1:11]].
"Hannah became pregnant"
The word "house" is a metonym for the people who lived in the house. AT: "his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
stops drinking milk and starts eating only solid food

tn.ref: he may appear before Yahweh and live there forever
tn.text: Hannah had promised God that she would allow Samuel to live and work with Eli the priest in the temple ([[:en:bible:notes:1sa:01:11|1:11]]).
"gave her son milk"
An ephah is about 22 liters of dry material. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
Wine was kept in animal skins, not glass bottles.

tn.ref: Oh, my master! As you live, my master
tn.text: Here the idiom "As you live" shows that Hannah is being sincere and truthful. AT: "Sir, what I am going to tell you is certainly true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: has given me my petition which I asked of him
tn.text: Hannah speaks as if a petition were a physical object that one person could give another, and she speaks of a petition as if it were the answer to the petition that she made. The abstract noun "petition" can be translated as a verb phrase. AT: "has agreed to do what I solemnly requested that he do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This can be translated in active form. AT: "I am loaning him to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"He" refers to Elkanah, but the UDB and many other versions regard this as metonymy for Elkanah and his family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
